Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: They quietly repeat a short mantra during their day without following the full ritual.
Story: Every Sunday, I try to send a text to my stepmother, just a simple “How are you?” or “Hope you’re well.” She always replies with warmth, but I sense her longing for more—maybe a call, maybe a visit. I know she wants to feel included, to bridge the gap that still lingers between us. At the same time, my father expects me to honor my Hindu roots, to perform the daily puja with incense, flowers, and prayers. But lately, I’ve only managed to whisper a mantra under my breath between classes or while waiting for the bus. I feel guilty, as if I’m letting down both sides—my stepmother, who wants connection, and my father, who wants tradition. The weight of their expectations presses on me, and I wonder if I can ever be enough for either of them. My phone buzzes with a new message from my stepmother just as I catch myself skipping the evening aarti again. I stare at the screen, torn, unsure which part of myself to answer first.
